head.title: **Non-linear Cyclic Codes that Attain the Gilbert-Varshamov Bound**
head.abstract: We prove that there exist non-linear binary cyclic codes that attain the Gilbert-Varshamov bound.

outline._note: For a finite field , a CYCLIC CODE of length is a linear subspace that is closed under cyclic permutations, i.e., for every codeword , all cyclic permutations of are also included in . Cyclic codes have been extensively studied over the last decades exhibiting a rich algebraic structure with immense applications in storage and communication, e.g., . A code over alphabet is said to have (NORMALIZED) MINIMUM DISTANCE at least if any two distinct codewords in are of Hamming distance at least . It is also said to have RATE . Of particular interest are GOOD FAMILIES OF CODES, which are sequences of codes , with of length , rate , and minimum normalized distance , such that simultaneously, One of the most fundamental challenges in coding theory is to construct good families of codes. Several such families were presented in the literature over the years. This includes, for example, the Gilbert-Varshamov (GV) codes and the algebraic constructions of Justesen and Goppa (see also ). However, the existence of a good family of CYCLIC (linear) codes is a long-standing open problem, see e.g., . In an attempt to shed some light on the problem of good cyclic codes, some works considered close variants to cyclic codes. Quasi-cyclic and double-circulant codes are one example, created by interleaving cyclic codes. These families were shown to contain families of good codes . Another such example is the family of module skew codes, which are almost cyclic except for a slight twist in the permutation. These were recently shown to contain a good family of codes . In this work, we study another variant of cyclic codes – NON-LINEAR cyclic codes[^1]. For simplicity of presentation we consider only the binary case. We will show that this family of codes contains a good family which asymptotically meets the GV bound , i.e., of normalized distance and asymptotic rate approaching , where stands for the binary entropy function. This matches the best known lower bound for binary codes of minimum normalized distance that are not necessarily cyclic. To the best of our knowledge, good families of non-linear binary cyclic codes have not been previously presented in the literature. Our construction of good binary non-linear cyclic codes is conceptually very simple and includes two steps. In the first step we construct a high-rate binary code which we call AUTO-CYCLIC. (All formal definitions are given below in Section .) An auto-cyclic code is a non-linear cyclic code in which the set of cyclic permutations of any given codeword is of (normalized) minimum distance at least . In this context, we refer to as the AUTO-CYCLIC distance. Auto-cyclic codes are reminiscent of ORTHOGONAL or low AUTO-CORRELATION codes, e.g. . Using a probabilistic argument, we show the existence of a subset of of asymptotic rate which is auto-cyclic with auto-cyclic distance arbitrarily close to . Once a high-rate auto-cyclic code is established, we greedily remove some of its elements (using a slight variant of the well known greedy process that leads to the GV bound) to obtain the desired non-linear cyclic code of rate and minimum distance . The remainder of this note is structured as follows. In Section we present our formal definitions. In Section we prove the existence of binary non-linear cyclic codes that meet the GV bound. Section includes concluding remarks and open questions. [^1]: It is common in the literature to define cyclic codes as linear. Thus, we shall make it a point to emphasize the fact that the codes we consider MAY BE non-linear by naming them NON-LINEAR CYCLIC CODES.

In this work we proved the existence of a good family of binary non-linear cyclic codes of normalized distance and asymptotic rate (i.e., codes that meet the GV bound). Whether the first step of our construction can be refined using algebraic techniques to yield a linear auto-cyclic code, or whether the second step of our construction (assuming a linear ) can yield a linear code , are intriguing problems left open in this work. Problems that, if solved, may shed light on the existence of good binary linear cyclic codes.
